## 1. Introduction

In general, we will explore how do experiences during youth and social interventions influence the financial stability and adult lives of at risk youth. More specifically, we will look for the impact of traumatic events on the financial independence of at risk youth in adulthood, and the help of social affairs interventions, improving their income levels, a goal that was set by the Israeli government many years ago (see link in appendix 1).

Traumatic events experienced during youth can negatively impact various aspects of life, including education, independence, and financial stability. This analysis aims to understand the effect of social affairs interventions on an individuals connection between traumatic experiences during youth and future financial stability and independence.

This problem is challenging due to the difficulty in collecting accurate income and retrospective information on youth ages. Retrospective data collection often suffers from inconsistencies, making it less reliable. However, the project overcomes this challenge by utilizing longitudinal data collected in real-time during younger ages, providing more reliable and fresh information.\
Most researches we found, for example TAU's research of barriers in at-risk youth development (see Appendix 2), only refer to general phenomenons with negative effect, rather than diving into specific welfare services, testing for both negative and positive impacts.\
Understanding this connection is crucial for developing effective interventions and support systems to improve the long-term outcomes of at-risk youth.

Our approach involves analyzing the data, tracking both childhood traumas and welfare service related features with the biggest effect about adulthood income, than using them in a prediction model, in order to prioritize specific welfare services interventions towards youth at-risk with different traumas, who need it the most, thus possibly hinting how to pull at-risk youth out of the cycle of poverty, helping them live an independent life, without continuous dependence on the welfare services.

## 2. Data

Our data is:"Trajectories of at-risk youth (longitudinal data)", by Dr. Talia Schwartz-Tayri.

Each entity represents youth-at risk, with a total of 471 entities,209 of which completed the whole surveys and will be included in our work. The data describes the results of 3 consequent surveys- the first one occured when they were 16-17 years old, before leaving the village. the second one, few months after they left the village and the third one was taken a few years after the second survey when they were 23 - 24 years old. The surveys include emotional, mental, financial and social feature families, which will be relevant to our analysis. The features include numerical, of which part are scalar and part are not, and textual variables. Each time period includes variables regarding the individual's relationships with family & educational staff at boarding school, as well as the skills they have acquired, hopes and expectations about the future and more.

All variables with T3 in the column name (for example, T3education_level) are from the third and final survey. All variables with T2 or B in the column name (for example, ActSeekMentalT2 or B.RAKAZ.SUPPORT) are from the second, mid-point survey. All variables with T1 or nothing extra (nothing of B, T2, T3) in the column name (for example, T1age or country) are from the first survey.

## 3. Methods and results

Our first step in the project was cleaning the data, reducing the dimensions of the data to only the features we might need in our analysis. Next, we decided to use two methods to try answer our question: The first method is regular linear regression after feature importance without model algorithm, and the second method is ordinal regression with regularization. The goal of using two different methods is to see if we get the same features from them both, what will strengthen the results.

For the linear regression, we modified our outcome feature, the income level of youth-at-risk in adulthood, making it useful in linear regression. Because we still had big variable amount, we used feature importance, without model, algorithm on our data, extracting the 50 most important predictors to our outcome variable (appendix 3). We replaced missing values in the median value of each feature, as we found that using the median is the most efficient & accurate way to do so. After fitting the model, we took the 29 variables with the lowest p-value (appendix 4). Linear model indicators results:

library(ggcorrplot)
library(caret)

excluded_column <- c(136,179,189, 200, 207, 209)

```{r , echo=FALSE, error=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
library(haven)
library(recipes)

clean_data <- clean_data%>%
  mutate(income_level = case_when(income_level==1 ~ 0, income_level==2 ~ 2000, income_level==3 ~ 3000,
income_level==4 ~ 4000, income_level==5 ~ 5000,
income_level==6 ~ 6000, income_level==7 ~ 7500,
income_level==8 ~ 10000, income_level==9 ~ 14000,
income_level==10 ~ 21000, income_level==11 ~ 0))
# using feature importance
roc_imp <- filterVarImp(x = clean_data[,column_range], y = clean_data$income_level)
roc_imp <- data.frame(cbind(variable = rownames(roc_imp), score = roc_imp[,1]))
roc_imp$score <- as.double(roc_imp$score)
roc_imp<-roc_imp[order(roc_imp$score,decreasing = TRUE),]

### only selecting out of the 50 most important variables:
variable_values <- roc_imp$variable
values <- head(variable_values, 50)

### removing the least significant variables to our model: 
important_features <- clean_data%>%
  dplyr::select(values,income_level, -B.LIFE.SKILLS.ALL_4, -T3education_courses, -T3_ACE_8, -T3_ACE_9,
-T3_15.230_2, -T3_welfare_service_2_4, -T3_welfare_service_2_9,
-Hacha9, -V35.8, -T3_15.230_1, -T3place_staff_freq, -T3staffandRakaz_help_2_3,
-HelpSeekInten2, -B.CONTACT.INITIATE, -B.HELP.EDUC, -T3_10.150, -T3_SRH, -T3_10.150.1,
-B.FUTURE.EXPECT.ALL_6, -Hacha2, -B.LIFE.SKILLS.ALL_7, -T3_welfare_service_2_7,
-B.STUDY.COVID)%>% 
  mutate(across(everything(), as.numeric))%>%
  mutate_all(~ replace_na(., median(., na.rm = TRUE)))

set.seed(1116)
# Put 80% of the data into the training set 
youth_split <- initial_split(important_features, prop = 0.80)
# Create data frames for the two sets:
train_data <- training(youth_split)
test_data  <- testing(youth_split)
```

```{r , echo=FALSE, error=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
# Building recipe
youth_rec <- recipe(
 income_level ~ ., # formula
 data = train_data # data to use for cataloguing names and types of variables
 )
# Define model
youth_mod <- linear_reg() %>%
  set_engine("lm")
# Define workflow
youth_wflow <- workflow() %>%
 add_model(youth_mod) %>%
 add_recipe(youth_rec)
# Fit model to training data
youth_fit <- youth_wflow %>%
 fit(data = train_data)
```

```{r }
train_pred <- predict(youth_fit, train_data) %>%
 bind_cols(train_data %>% dplyr::select(income_level))%>%
  mutate(.pred = ifelse(.pred < 0, 0, .pred))

# Calculate the mean squared error (MSE)
train_rmse <- RMSE(train_pred$income_level, train_pred$.pred)

test_pred <- predict(youth_fit, test_data) %>%
 bind_cols(test_data %>% dplyr::select(income_level))%>%
  mutate(.pred = ifelse(.pred < 0, 0, .pred))


# Calculate the mean squared error (MSE)
test_rmse <- RMSE(test_pred$income_level, test_pred$.pred)

cat("RMSE score:", test_rmse, "\n")
```

Using cross-validation:

```{r}
# Set the seed
set.seed(1116)

# Create a vfold cross-validation object
youth_vfold <- vfold_cv(train_data, v = 10)  # Specify the number of folds you want to use

# Define the updated workflow
youth_wflow <- workflow() %>%
  add_model(youth_mod) %>%
  add_recipe(youth_rec)

# Fit and evaluate the model using cross-validation
youth_fit_cv <- youth_wflow %>%
  fit_resamples(resamples = youth_vfold)
# Get the summary statistics for R-squared and adjusted R-squared
collect_metrics(youth_fit_cv)

```

The 10 most impactful features (5 positive and 5 negative) and their impact:

```{r, echo=FALSE, out.width="50%", out.height="50%", warning=FALSE}
# Extract the coefficients from the fitted model
coefficients <- tidy(youth_fit)[-1, ]

# Sort the coefficients based on their absolute values
sorted_coeffs <- coefficients[order(coefficients$estimate, decreasing = TRUE), ]

# Select the top 5 predictors with the largest positive impact
top_positive_predictors <- head(sorted_coeffs, 5)
# Select the top 5 predictors with the largest negative impact
top_negative_predictors <- tail(sorted_coeffs, 5)

# Combine the positive and negative predictors
top_predictors <- rbind(top_positive_predictors, top_negative_predictors)

top_predictors$term <- factor(top_predictors$term,
levels = top_predictors$term[order(-top_predictors$estimate)])

# Define new labels for the predictors
new_labels <- c("Ethnical Discrimination" = "T3_21.140_2",
                "Looking for Job" = "T3job_seeking",
                "Probation Officer at Youth" = "T3_welfare_service_1_9_2",
                "Having an Apartment in Future" = "B.FUTURE.EXPECT.ALL_5",
                "Having a Mentor" = "Mentor",
                "Contact with Alumni Coordinator" = "B.CONTACT.WHO_rakaz",
                "Family Treatment at Youth" = "T3_welfare_service_1_3_2",
                "Contact Frequency with Village Staff" = "B_contact_frequency",
                "Yated Social Worker Help Level" = "T3_welfare_service_2_11",
                "Other Welfare Services at Youth" = "T3_welfare_service_1_12_2")

# Recode the labels of the predictors
top_predictors <- top_predictors %>%
  mutate(term = fct_recode(term, !!!new_labels))

# Create a bar plot of the top 10 predictors
ggplot(top_predictors, aes(x = estimate, y = term,
fill = ifelse(estimate >= 0, "Positive", "Negative"))) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", color = "white") +
  labs(x = "Coefficient Estimate", y = "Predictors",
       title = "Most Impactful Predictors by Coefficient Estimate",
 subtitle = "Linear regression predictors fitted to training data",
 caption = "Data: Trajectories of at-risk youth (longitudinal data), by Dr. Talia Schwartz-Tayri ") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("#ef3b2c", "#74c476"), guide = FALSE) +
  theme_minimal()
```

For the ordinal regression, we performed regularization and then build an ordinal regression model. Full results in appendix 5. Indicators results:

```{r, echo=FALSE, error=FALSE, warning=FALSE, include=FALSE}
set.seed(1116)
require(foreign)
require(ggplot2)
require(MASS)
require(Hmisc)
require(reshape2)
require(caret)


# Define the control parameters for the random forest model
ctrl <- trainControl(method = "cv",   # Cross-validation
                     number = 10,      # Number of folds
                     verboseIter = FALSE)  # Display progress

# Train the random forest model using the train() function
model <- train(income_level ~ .,              # Formula specifying dependent variable and predictors
               data = train_data_ord_fct,       # Training data
               method = "rf",                 # Random forest method
               trControl = ctrl,              # Control parameters
               tuneLength=25)               

# Print the model results
print(model)
```

```{r, echo=FALSE, error=FALSE, warning=FALSE, include=FALSE}
# Calculate variable importance
importance <- varImp(model)

# Get the top 30 predictors
top30_indices <- order(importance$importance[, "Overall"], decreasing = TRUE)[1:30]
top30_predictor_names <- rownames(importance$importance)[top30_indices]

selected_columns_subset_fct <- train_data_ord_fct[, c(top30_predictor_names, "income_level")]

require(foreign)
require(ggplot2)
require(MASS)
require(Hmisc)
require(reshape2)

m <- polr(income_level ~ ., data = selected_columns_subset_fct, Hess=TRUE , method = "probit")
summary(m)

ctable <- coef(summary(m))
p <- pnorm(abs(ctable[, "t value"]), lower.tail = FALSE) * 2
ctable <- cbind(ctable, "p value" = p)
ctable
predicted <- predict(m, newdata = test_data_ord_fct, type = "class")

actual <- test_data_ord_fct$income_level

```

We found out that the two models gives very different features as the most important features. Therefore, We have no absolute certainty for any of the features. We prefer the features of the linear regression model because their features' p-value is much lower, its' rmse is a bit lower as well, and both childhood traumas features & welfare services features, which are more related to our research question, get bigger importance in the linear regression model than the ordinal regression one. The explanation of the meaning of the features we found see appendix.

Even though the linear regression did provide better results than the ordinary one, it's still has its limitations towards our initial hypothesis-as seen both in the coefficients scores and the regression measures(r\^2, adjusted r\^2, rmse). In our training data, youth having a mentor, and having probation officer at youth had a negative effect on the income at adulthood. However, ethnical discrimination did reduce the income level at adulthood. Moreover, the higher contact frequency with village's staff, as well as other social services, the higher future income will be.

## 4.Limitations and Future Work

A significant limitation of our data analysis is the data size and the relatively small percentage of the entities we have all the data about(the youth at-risk who completed all of the surveys), which caused high p-values at many features in our model, and harmed the indexes. Although the data is good enough in our project, its size cannot indicate a more widespread phenomenon around at-risk youth, and does not allow us to make concrete conclusions. We may have gotten fine results replacing missing values in the median, but we are sure that there are better, more efficient and effective ways dealing with missing data. Additional months for improving our analysis would have provided us the opportunity to find more comprehensive and deeper examination of the right method dealing with missing values. Furthermore, Our analysis does not consider demographic factors, which might be important as well. Analyzing subgroups based on origin, for example, might have indicated different results.\
Moreover, additional months working on our project would allow us to include additional external data, which would improve the measures, and to explore our research question across a variety of countries, dividing the data into ethnic groups as-well. Moreover, we would have assessed welfare services interventions' effectiveness in improving not only the financial aspects of at-risk youth, but also their overall well-being at the future.
